description: Help students understand the concept of grouping and repeated grouping.

standards.description: Interpret the products of whole numbers, such as interpreting 5 Ã— 7 as the total number of objects in 5 groups of 7 objects each.

inputs.label: How do you feel about repeated addition?
inputs.name: e5992fd2-c0b3-4408-b66a-39a383f0a58e

activities.name: Start block
activities.prompt: Drag a start block onto the canvas

activities.name: Start block and Circle block
activities.description: Learn about the start block and circle block
activities.prompt: Drag a start block and a circle block onto the canvas and connect them together.

reflections.message: By connecting the two blocks you told the computer to draw a circle. You have written code!

activities.name: Connecting multiple blocks together
activities.description: Learn about connecting multiple blocks together
activities.prompt: Tell the computer to draw 5 circles by connecting 5 circle blocks to the start block.

reflections.message: We are telling our computer to add. In this case our equation looks like this: 1 circle + 1 circle + 1 circle + 1 circle + 1 circle = 5 circles

activities.name: The Repeat Block
activities.description: Learn about the repeat block. In this activity you will observe the default behavior of the repeat block. You should expect it to repeat the action inside it the number of times found in the input.
activities.prompt: Connect a repeat block to the start block and then place a circle block inside of the repeat block.

reflections.message: We just told the computer to do the same thing as before. This time we only used two blocks.

activities.name: Adjusting the Repeat Block
activities.description: Learn how to adjust the repeat block.
activities.prompt: Tell the computer to draw 7 circles using the repeat block by changing the number from 5 to 7.

activities.name: A lot of repeating
activities.description: Learn about placing one repeat block inside another one.
activities.prompt: Place one of the repeat blocks inside another one. Then place a draw circle block into the repeat block.

reflections.message: We have just taught our computer to do repeated addition. We have several rows with the same number of items in each row. Repeated addition is also called multiplication. Multiplication is where we take groups of equal sizes and add all of their items together.

activities.name: Multiplying using the repeat block
activities.description: Modify the defaults of the nested repeat blocks
activities.prompt: Using the two repeat blocks, where one repeat block is inside another repeat block, tell the computer to multiply by drawing 3 circles 4 times.

reflections.message: By counting we know that there are 12 circles total.

activities.name: Multiplying
activities.prompt: Tell the computer multiply by telling it to repeat 4 circles 3 times.

reflections.message: By counting all the circles we know that there are 12 circles again. That was the same as last time. 3 groups of 4 makes the same number as 4 groups of 3.

In math we write it like this: 3 x 4 = 12
 This means that we have 3 groups of 4 items and there are 12 items total.
If we had 5 groups of 3 items, we would write it like this: 5 x 3
To get our computer to do this for us we would use 2 repeat blocks like before. Then we would modify the first one to have 5 as its value and the second one would have 3 as its value.

activities.name: Applying multiplication
activities.prompt: Tell the computer to multiply: 5 x 3

inputs.label: How do you feel about repeated addition?
inputs.name: f341062b-1f12-4ef1-aeb0-64b1134bdebe

inputs.label: How hard was it to tell the computer to do our math?
inputs.name: 0287366a-7b43-4540-a7d1-413b6798e53b
